The bill in question: H.R. 3525, known as the "U.S. Border Patrol Medical Screening Standards Act," focused on improving medical screenings of immigrants who cross the border illegally, particularly vulnerable populations such as children, pregnant women, and the elderly.
The bill required the Chief Information: in coordination with the Chief Medical Officer, to establish an electronic health record system within the department that can be accessed by all components operating along the borders of the United States for individuals in their custody.
The legislation did not address veterans: medical care or impact their waiting times for services, contrary to the misleading claim made in the headline.
While U: S. Customs and Border Protection was already working on developing an electronic health records system, the bill aimed to expedite the process by setting a 90-day deadline for its implementation.
